story:
A Little Bit About Myself:

                                    


My name is Danielle Damask. I am 20 years old and am aspiring to be a physician in the near future who educates and assists others so that they can take full advantage of the truly amazing gift we were given, life. As for now, I am taking advantage of every opportunity that I can so that I can better myself and can better the world around me. I am presently attending the University of Wisconsin - Parkside where I am double majoring in Biology and Applied Health Science. I work at Brookside Care Center in Kenosha County, WI as a Certified Nursing Assistant assisting the elderly in every way I possibly can to make sure they are living comfortably and blissfully. Also, I am in the Army National Guard, working as a Chemical, Biological, Radiological, & Nuclear (CBRN) Specialist, trained to protect our nation if ever need be.

My Campaign:

I am trying to raise $3,000 so that I can attend a medical mission trip to Ometepe island located in Nicaragua, one of the poorest countries in the western hemisphere. In Nicaragua I will be working from 9:00 AM - 5:00 PM alongside Nicaraguan and U.S. physicians and physically observing how medicine is practiced in third world countries without the hi-tech equipment that we are accustomed to using in the United States. In addition, alongside physicians I will be allowed to assist in some of the procedures. In addition to being able to learn and assist, my fellow peers and I will be bringing about 70 lbs of medication each as a part of our luggage which will then be distributed by local doctors in the rural clinics.

Patients are not expected to pay with money, instead each patient is asked to bring used batteries as a form of payment for each free appointment and any medication they may need. Doing so also helps us eliminate some one the toxic waste in Nicaragua since there are no recycling facilities there. If they do not have batteries we take in plastic garbage as a form of payment.

Attending this trip would be an astonishing, once in lifetime experience for me and would allow me to make a difference in other people's lives who are less fortunate and need it. The government presence in this rural area is very limited so the funding for this project is done solely by payments of the students that participate in the project, or myself, which is why I want to diligently work to earn/raise the money for the mission trip.

The Funding Breakdown:

In order to attend the medical mission trip to Nicaragua I need to raise 3,000. This money will cover the fees of me getting to the island and in addition some of the money is used to pay for the medication and the doctors in the clinics so that we can successfully treat the patients in Nicaragua.

Perks:

                      

For every $5.00 donated your name will be entered in a raffle for a trip (if you donate more than $5.00 your name will be entered more than once).

The raffle prizes are as follows:

1st Prize: Bahama's Vacation for 2 + $100.00
2nd Prize: Las Vegas Vacation for 2 + $75.00
3rd Prize: $50.00

The drawing for this raffle will be held on March 1, 2015. Winner does not need to be present to be eligible to win.

I recently won the vacations which are strictly promotional, not a time share vacation, and although they truly sounded amazing I decided they would be better used to raise money and awareness for those who are less fortunate. This year, 2015, I want to give back to others and make others smile, because ultimately, other people's happiness is what drives me to keep going, keep challenging myself, and is what makes me truly happy.

Prizes

The first prize includes:

2 Night Cruise for two abroad the Bahamas Celebration Cruise Ship to the Grant Bahama Island with all the meals, entertainment, and activities included on board! In addition, it includes 3 days and 2 nights prior to docking the cruise ship in sun-kissed Fort Lauderdale, Florida, with complimentary buffet dining for 2 adults (3 meals per day per person).
+ $100.00 cash to be used however you'd like.

The second prize includes:

3 days & 2 nights in the exciting Las Vegas, Nevada!
+ $75.00 cash to be used however you'd like.

The third prize includes:

$50.00 cash to be used however you'd like.

Handmade Crochet Infinity Scarves


                           

                  

                  

These scarves are perfect to wear with anything and are super warm & soft. I can make any color desired. Each scarf takes about an hour or more to make so although the price is expensive that includes the material, time, and shipping as well. I fall in love with every single one I make, they're perfect! Shipping is as soon as possible, March at the latest.

Other Ways You Can Help

I am well aware that money is tight these days and if possible, just a $5.00 donation could help me reach my goal and help others immensely! But if not, simply just sharing my information about fundraising could help me a lot as well and I appreciate all the help I can get tremendously!

Thank you for your time and consideration regarding my medical mission trip fundraising project!
story_txt:
A Little Bit About Myself:

                                     
 My name is Danielle Damask. I am 20 years old and am aspiring to be a physician in the near future who educates and assists others so that they can take full advantage of the truly amazing gift we were given, life. As for now, I am taking advantage of every opportunity that I can so that I can better myself and can better the world around me. I am presently attending the University of Wisconsin - Parkside where I am double majoring in Biology and Applied Health Science. I work at Brookside Care Center in Kenosha County, WI as a Certified Nursing Assistant assisting the elderly in every way I possibly can to make sure they are living comfortably and blissfully. Also, I am in the Army National Guard, working as a Chemical, Biological, Radiological, & Nuclear (CBRN) Specialist, trained to protect our nation if ever need be.

My Campaign:
I am trying to raise $3,000 so that I can attend a medical mission trip to Ometepe island located in Nicaragua, one of the poorest countries in the western hemisphere. In Nicaragua I will be working from 9:00 AM - 5:00 PM  alongside Nicaraguan and U.S.
physicians and physically observing how medicine is practiced in third world
countries without the hi-tech equipment that we are accustomed to using in the
United States. In addition, alongside physicians I will be allowed to assist in some of the procedures. In addition to being able to learn and assist, my fellow peers and I will be bringing about 70 lbs of medication each as a part of our luggage which will then be distributed by local doctors in the rural clinics.Patients are not expected to pay with money, instead each patient is asked to bring used batteries as a form of payment for each free appointment and any medication they may need. Doing so also helps us eliminate some one the toxic waste in Nicaragua since there are no recycling facilities there. If they do not have batteries we take in plastic garbage as a form of payment. Attending this trip would
be an astonishing, once in lifetime experience for me and would allow me to make a difference in other people's lives who are less fortunate and need it. The government

story:
Short Summary


Who We Are


We are Universities Allied for Essential Medicines (UAEM): an internationally renowned network of students and researchers that are working tirelessly to make access to essential, life-saving medicines a reality for everyone across the world. In the last 2 years, our students have run campaigns at our universities, met with government ministries and have advised on parliamentary select committees, as well as and spoken at international institutions such as the World Health Organisation, run the world's first Access to Medicines Week and launched the UK’s first Global Health League Table. Almost all of our work is driven by committed students, on a completely voluntary, non-profit basis.



Why is this important?

Today, a third of the world lacks access to affordable medicines. These are the drugs needed to treat severely disabling, or even life-threatening diseases. These are the drugs that don’t exist because they’re not profitable enough to interest the pharmaceutical industry. These are drugs that every health system needs. These are drugs that every human being has a right to. As students, we work to make sure that our universities, who discover many of these drugs, do not neglect the diseases of the poor. Access to medicines should never be sacrificed for financial gain!



What We Need & What You Get


This April, we are holding a conference in London for 200 students from all over Europe. Over one weekend, we will educate, inspire, and give a voice to a rising network. We will connect them with each other and with experts in the field. We will give them the tools to reach out for social justice and have a real impact on the research and development of life-saving medicines.


The London Conference will be the inspirational backbone to a year of campaigning throughout Europe. In the past year, we have had unprecedented success - but we want to continue striving towards a better world. With your support we can reach that together.


Specifically, we have three core aims:

  • Provide students with knowledge, confidence and skills necessary to speak to faculty members, politicians and members of the public to discuss the difficult topic of universal access to medicine.

  • Inspire and empower students to embody the change they wish to see in the world.

  • Bring together 200 students from over 20 countries to foster a community built on the principles of respect, equality, and justice.



To run the conference of our dreams, we estimate a budget of approximately £15,000. This includes:


  • Accommodation and food for two hundred students  

  • Means to invite fifteen ground breaking speakers and expert workshop facilitators

  • Venue rental

  • Conference materials

  • Publicity

  • Travel funding for conference disadvantaged participants



These are expected costs for an international student conference, but there are a couple of unique aspects about it:


  • We believe that personal finances should never be a barrier to participation. So, uniquely for a conference, we want to provide travel funding for students that needs it.

  • This conference is being run, and organised, by a team of student volunteers, all while studying for their degrees. For us, this is an incredible learning opportunity, and a chance to make a lasting impact on the lives of our student friends.

We will use your funding to pay for items that have otherwise been difficult to raise money for, in particular, focussing on those students in greatest financial need. If we manage to satisfy that, we will use the remaining money to fund other areas of the budget.


The Impact


This year, we plan on breaking the traditional mould of didactic learning. We are creating a flexible, engaging, and member driven approach to the conference, that will deliver maximum participation and ensure sparks are flying from day one.


Our conferences make sure that we have a large, skilled, and motivated volunteer base necessary to maintain activism across Europe. We make considerable efforts to connect our members through virtual means, but nothing can replace the power of an in-person meeting. All of our projects are given momentum through the mutual exchange of ideas, materials, strategies, and feelings.


Perhaps the greatest impact it will have however, is on the lives of the students themselves. We believe that the best way to create change in our society is to focus on the leaders of tomorrow. UAEM, its principles, its activities, and its community occupy a special place in the heart of our members. By acting now to foster faith in the importance of social justice, we can change institutions from the bottom-up.


Risks & Challenges


Organising such a large conference in one of the busiest cities in the world with a student team of volunteers will not be easy. With patience and dedication, we are confident we will succeed.

The biggest challenge is making sure we get enough funds to make sure the conference manages to go ahead. Our fundraising team is currently working hard behind the scenes to make this a reality. Their strategy has included:

  • Contacting every major university in London

  • Contacting ethical food providers for donations

  • Submitting numerous fundraising applications to foundations and trusts

  • Creating a 'name your own price' ticketing system that will allow members to subsidise each other.

Our logistics team, on the other hand, are exploring options to make the conference as affordable as possible:

  • Housing students in local sports halls, and in peoples' homes.

  • Cooking as much of the food as possible ourselves

  • Asking speakers to cover as much of their own costs as possible

  • Encouraging members to pursue carbon-light, low-cost travel.

  • Hosting a vegetarian conference.


Other Ways You Can Help

Don't worry if you can't donate, there are other ways you can support our cause!

  • Spread the word about the conference to your friends!

  • If you are a student yourself, check out our website, and get involved!

  • Join the discussing by following us on facebook and twitter!

  • Check out our latest project, the University Global Health Research League Table

story:
EducationHOPE is an initiative that seeks to provide holistic educational opportunities to financially disadvantaged students from very rural areas where there are scarce resources, around the Lake Victoria region. This is an initiative that was initiated and is run by a student from the same Lake Victoria region who is today is in school,( EARTH University, Costa Rica)because there are people who believed in him and helped him access opportunities.Being the first person to get into college from his community, David is  a role model to many of students from his community who cannot be in school because of the high cost of education which their parents who live in extreme poverty conditions cannot afford. He started this initiative as a call to help the students he had motivated to when he won his full scholarship to study abroad be able to go to school. Today, the number keeps on rising.


Why the Fundraising?

Majimbo is a small village along the shore of the Lake Victoria where fishing and small scale farming are the main economic activities. Most of the families live on less than $1 a day. It is a community where education is not a priority because education has to be paid for in Kenya. Beyond education, Majimbo faces a major threat in terms of HIV/AIDS and STIs which according to the recent research stands at 56%, a sad reality that does not only influence the kind of life here but also the future of the community. The following are the major reasons for the fundraising;
  1. Scholarships
Majimbo had its first ever college student last year when David won a scholarship to study in Costa Rica at EARTH University under the full support of the MasterCard Foundation. This was a great motivation to many school going students and for the first time, 20 students from this community joined high school. High school education in Kenya is not free, parents pay up to $2000 annually in public schools. In Majimbo however, the parents cannot at times cannot afford meals for their families - education will definately get the least priority. School dropouts has always been a culture even before graduating from primary school. Boys drop out from as early as 11 to start taking part in the family upkeep while the girls get pregnant even as young as 13. We really need your help to make this difference.
We need your support to provide comprehensive scholarships to 50 chiildren who need at least $600 annually to be able to stay in school. This is meant to cover their accommodation, food, tuition, books and uniform.
 2.  Sanitary Pads
Most of the girl child dropouts in Majimbo are directly related the fact that they do cannot access sanitary pads and the appropriate sanitary and hygiene awareness. Although boys are allowed to study and work, culturally, girls cannot do anything and when difficult time come, they opt to sell their bodies to the man around who can in exchange give them some little money to help them buy stuff like sanitary pads because if not they would not be able to attend school. Because of this, they end up getting pregnant in their teens and if not end up being HIV/AIDS positive. Girls are the future of the world. They also need to be educated.
We hope to provide all our students with regular sanitary pads to help them stay in school
  3.  Solar Lamps

Imagine living in a world without electricity. Where you cannot only have to watch television or use your telephone but also have to take dinner before darkness sets and go without doing your homework. This is the situation in Majimbo. Students cannot do their assignments because there is no light to do so, they cannot study like the rest. If they happen to have kerosene lanterns, they cannot afford the kerosene regularly.

We want to provide hope for the students by giving them an opportunity to also study and do homework like the rest


Why is Your Contribution Important?

The community we are working to change is one that has had a very negative school enrollment and very huge numbers of dropouts. In fact, only one has managed to get into the university (David, the founder EducationHOPE). Among the factors, the main one is the poverty levels that are so high in this community, literally every household lives on less than $1 every day. So many students cannot go to school because their families cannot afford to pay their school fees, a necessity since education has to be paid for by students in Kenyan high schools.

Imagine the impact you are creating not only for the students but for their families and also their communities. Educating one child can change the world, but you are going beyond this with your support to create a motivation, show a possibility and beyond all this, building a future for someone whom without you cannot make it.

With your support, these students will forget the trouble and worry of being sent out of school and instead peacefully stay in school just like their fellow students.

Help Make the difference


What We Have Done

Begun five months ago, EducationHOPE has already provided scholarships to 8 boys 6 girls in three different schools fro the support of people like. We can never be any happier than seeing our students full of smiles

         Photo: Part of the group of our first supported students


What You Will Support

The $20000 target is meant to help provide scholarships for the first half of the next academic year to all our students, provide sanitary pads and also a single LuminAID solar lamps to the families of each student. The collected funds are sent directly to the bank accounts of the various schools. The rest will be used to purchase the lamps from LuminAID and sanitary pads to the students.

We are in the process of forming an NGO to keep supporting more. If you wish to be part of us, please check out our perks and find our interesting offers. We are so grateful for your support. 

Every dollar raised will go directly towards those in need in the focus areas stated above.


Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help us share our campaign with your friends, colleagues and family through social media and even emails.

You can find us on facebook on the link below

https://www.facebook.com/ruralkidhope/?pnref=lhc

Visit our website to support us and also learn more about EducationHOPE

http://www.educationhope.org/

What You Will Support

The collected funds are sent directly to the bank accounts of the various schools. The rest will be used to purchase the lamps from LuminAID and sanitary pads to the students.

story:
Campaign Overview

Please help the Beamer 'ohana bring ukuleles and hands-on music and dance instruction to impoverished children in rural Cambodia.  In cooperation with Mohala Hou Foundation in Hawaii and The Ponheary Ly Foundation in Cambodia, this campaign seeks funding to purchase musical instruments, develop instructional materials, and organize and present a series of music and dance lessons for at least 40 Cambodian children.   

In Cambodia, children in rural villages face an uphill battle against poverty and limited access to education when compared to children in urban areas.  Many impoverished children in rural Cambodia don’t have access to money to buy uniforms and their school supplies in order to attend primary school.   The Ponheary Ly Foundation (PLF) provides children who would not otherwise be attending school with these essentials.  Once all the children from a village are present at their school and properly equipped, the PLF supports the school sufficiently to provide a quality of education that is equal to that which is accessible in the urban communities.

Mohala Hou Foundation (MHF) is a non-profit organization that presents Aloha Music Camp (AMC) and other educational and cultural programs to foster understanding and perpetuation of Hawaiian culture.  Through AMC, the Beamer 'ohana and other Hawaiian Kumu (teachers) have provided teaching and cultural context in ukulele, guitar hula, olelo (language), oli (chant), and traditional Hawaiian crafts to thousands of participants of all ages over the years.  The expertise of MHF in developing and presenting cultural enrichment programs ensures the Cambodian children will receive the highest quality of instruction that is responsive to their needs and interests.

Our goal is to provide Cambodian kids with a way to enrich their lives and communities through the power of music and dance. Children will learn to better understand the essential connection of music and dance in other cultures, then begin to assimilate these ideas and instruments into their own culture. To begin this process, our instructors will teach the children Cambodian songs in their own language. By learning to play their own songs on their own instruments, then taking these instruments home to their villages, the warmth, joy and “aloha” of music will begin to spread and uplift the lives and hearts of their extended families. 

It's important to realize that many communities in Cambodia are without any modern conveniences and are often comprised of downtrodden and disadvantaged people. Your gift of education and music will make a big difference in the happiness and fulfillment of the lives of these Cambodian families.

In addition to the instruction and the educational materials we will deliver to the children, the  educational experience we provide will foster cross-cultural understanding and deeper bonds between our countries, teachers and students.


Our Instructors

While learning to play the ukulele need not be difficult, it certainly helps to have  world-class instructors.  While several of our instructors are best known as guitar players, they are also accomplished ukulele players--in fact, for some it was the ukulele that first introduced them to playing music during their childhood, long before they even picked up a guitar!

  • Keola Beamer is one of Hawai'i's premier singer/songwriters, arrangers, composers and Master Of The Hawaiian Slack Key Guitar. His well of talent springs from five generations of Hawai's most illustrious and beloved musical families. Keola's mother was revered Hawaiian Cultural Treasure, Aunty Nona Beamer. His great-grandmother was one of Hawai'i's most illustrious composers, Helen Desha Beamer. The Beamers trace their roots to the 14th century and have been cultural practitioners through generations.
  • Moanalani Beamer is a Kumu Hula (Hula Master)who began her hula training in 1960 at the age four with Kumu Hula, Johnny Hokoana. In her early years, she continued training extensively with several different Kumu in Hawaii. Through the years Moana has accumulated valuable teaching experience in the art of the Hula. Her sensitive nature combines her understanding of the technique with the spiritual and philosophical currents expressed in the Hula. Moana remains firmly committed to sharing her cultural knowledge worldwide.
  •  Jeff Peterson is recognized as one of Hawaii’s most versatile musicians. His passion for the guitar has allowed him to shine as a solo artist and has given him the opportunity to collaborate with a wide variety of artists from Hawaii, across the US, and abroad. He has contributed to two Grammy Award-winning recordings and has been honored with four Na Hōkū Hanohano Awards in Hawaii.    Born on the Island of Maui, Jeff Peterson grew up on the slopes of Haleakala where he was introduced to the rich heritage of Hawaiian music by his father, a paniolo, or Hawaiian cowboy, on the Haleakala Ranch.
  • Cindy Shenk has been playing the 'ukulele for many years.  She is a member of Walter Kawai'ai'ea's ukulele group, accenting the Kauhanu Lake style.  She plays at Pukalani Country Club with Honey Bun and the Coconuts on the Island of Maui.  Cindy brings a deep understanding of the instrument with a strong focus on early education.  Cindy has developed a gentle teaching style which will add immeasurably to this project.  In addition to teaching, she will help document workshops and performances in Cambodia as the students progress with their lessons.

  •  Tom Lunneberg has been a student of Keola Beamer for more than ten years, studying slack key guitar and deepening his understand of Hawaiian culture though participation in Aloha Music Camp.  He has released two albums of original instrumental works, and has been an Artist Advocate for Guitars in the Classroom since 2008.  Tom is the current President of Mohala Hou Foundation.  

Our Fundraising Goal

  • Our budget of $25,000 will provide instructional materials for at least 40 children, including their very own ukulele, tuner, and printed copies of the lessons.  The budget provides for organizing and presenting the educational sessions at a facility in Cambodia.  The budget also defrays travel costs for the volunteer team of instructors.  Depending on final costs for purchasing the instruments and shipping them to Cambodia, we hope to reach more than 40 students within our budget.
  • We want to reach as many students as possible and to provide them with quality, personalized instruction.  In the event that we do not reach our full funding goal, we will scale our approach accordingly to maximize its impact with the available budget.
  • To thank you for your generosity, contributions of $25 or more will receive (via e-mail) a signed digital photo of the students and instructors that will be taken during the lessons.  Contributions of $100 or more will receive (by mail) a printed photo of the students and instructors, signed by Keola Beamer.

Our Sponsors

  • The Ponheary Ly Foundation is a registered 501(c)3 non-profit organization in the USA. Their goal is to locate and serve the many children in Cambodia who live in the poorest rural villages and do not have access to equitable educational opportunities.

  • The Mohala Hou Foundation was established as a 501(c)3  non-profit organization in September 2007 to support and promote the teaching and sharing of Hawaiian music, dance, language, and culture.  The name Mohala Hou (meaning “to blossom anew”) conveys what we believe is essential for the Hawaiian culture: renewal, growth, and revitalization.  We believe that the perpetuation of "the aloha spirit" and many of Hawaiʻi's other traditional ideas and areas of knowledge is vital to maintain the cultural diversity so necessary to the world today.   We feel it is our kuleana (responsibility) to bring people together, both from Hawaiʻi locally and from the world at large, to allow for cultural enrichment by education in Hawaiian arts and traditional knowledge. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't make a financial contribution to our campaign, we will greatly appreciate if you can spread the word about what we are trying to accomplish through social media and other channels!
story_txt:
Campaign Overview Please help the Beamer 'ohana bring ukuleles and hands-on music and dance instruction to impoverished children in rural Cambodia.  In cooperation with Mohala Hou Foundation in Hawaii and The Ponheary Ly Foundation in Cambodia, this campaign seeks funding to purchase musical instruments, develop instructional materials, and organize and present a series of music and dance lessons for at least 40 Cambodian children.   
In Cambodia, children in rural villages face an uphill battle against poverty and limited access to education when compared to children in urban areas.  Many impoverished children in rural Cambodia don’t have access to money to buy uniforms and their school supplies in order to attend primary school.   The Ponheary Ly Foundation (PLF) provides children who would not otherwise be attending school with these essentials.  Once all the children from a village are present at their school and properly equipped, the PLF supports the school sufficiently to provide a quality of education that is equal to that which is accessible in the urban communities.
Mohala Hou Foundation (MHF) is a non-profit organization that presents Aloha Music Camp (AMC) and other educational and cultural programs to foster understanding and perpetuation of Hawaiian culture.  Through AMC, the Beamer 'ohana and other Hawaiian Kumu (teachers) have provided teaching and cultural context in ukulele, guitar hula, olelo (language), oli (chant), and traditional Hawaiian crafts to thousands of participants of all ages over the years.  The expertise of MHF in developing and presenting cultural enrichment programs ensures the Cambodian children will receive the highest quality of instruction that is responsive to their needs and interests.

Our goal is to provide Cambodian kids with a way to enrich their lives and communities through the power of music and dance. Children will learn to better understand the essential connection of music and dance in other cultures, then begin to assimilate these ideas and instruments into their own culture. To begin this process, our instructors will teach the children Cambodian songs in their own language. By learning to play their own songs on their own instruments, then taking these instruments home to their villages, the warmth, joy and “aloha” of music will begin to spread and uplift the lives and hearts of their extended families. 
It's important to realize that many communities in Cambodia are without any modern conveniences and are often comprised of downtrodden and disadvantaged people. Your gift of education and music will make a big difference in the happiness and fulfillment of the lives of these Cambodian families.
In addition to the instruction and the educational materials we will deliver to the children, the  educational experience we provide will foster cross-cultural understanding and deeper bonds between our countries, teachers and students.


Our Instructors
While learning to play the ukulele need not be difficult, it certainly helps to have  world-class instructors.  While several of our instructors are best known as guitar players, they are also accomplished ukulele players--in fact, for some it was the ukulele that first introduced them to playing music during their childhood, long before they even picked up a guitar!

In her early years, she continued training extensively with several different Kumu in Hawaii. Through the years Moana has accumulated valuable teaching experience in the art of the Hula. Her sensitive nature combines her understanding of the technique with the spiritual and philosophical currents expressed in the Hula. Moana remains firmly committed to sharing her cultural knowledge worldwide.  Jeff Peterson is recognized as one of Hawaii’s most versatile musicians. His passion for the guitar has allowed him to shine as a solo artist and has given him the opportunity to collaborate with a wide variety of artists from Hawaii, across the US, and abroad. He has contributed to two Grammy Award-winning recordings and has been honored with four Na Hōkū Hanohano Awards in Hawaii.    Born on the Island of Maui, Jeff Peterson grew up on the slopes of Haleakala where he was introduced to the rich heritage of Hawaiian music by his father, a paniolo, or Hawaiian cowboy, on the Haleakala Ranch.

Cindy Shenk has been playing the 'ukulele for many years.  She is a member of Walter Kawai'ai'ea's ukulele group, accenting the Kauhanu Lake style.  She plays at Pukalani Country Club with Honey Bun and the Coconuts on the Island of Maui.  Cindy brings a deep understanding of the instrument with a strong focus on early education.  Cindy has developed a gentle teaching style which will add immeasurably to this project.  In addition to teaching, she will help document workshops and performances in Cambodia as the students progress with their lessons.

story:
Each week, parents will bring their toddlers to participate in exciting guided letter & wordplay classes celebrating the magic of language.

Families laugh, dance, sing, craft, read, and move together - all while celebrating the alphabet!  

Parents want to set their children up for a lifetime of reading success - and they are always looking for fun, meaningful and engaging activities to do with their toddlers. JoyRead gives parents the opportunity to do both as they engage with their children around the basics of language in fun, exciting ways.

JoyRead offers parents a life-changing, eye-opening opportunity. We know that cultivating language and literacy skills is vital to a child's overall development. But did you know that this can be great fun? JoyRead shows parents how to cultivate early literacy with ease, playfulness and delight.  

Before children ever learn how to read and write, they need to learn the building blocks for language. JoyRead classes give parents a chance play with their toddlers while laying the foundation for future success in school, in socializing, in developing independence, and ultimately in managing money and work.

JoyRead gives parents a way fantastic way to set their children up for a brighter future.

The dynamic, creative JoyRead curriculum has already been successfully tried and tested. While  living overseas, I hosted the first-ever JoyRead classes at an American military base, and the response was overwhelming - parents and toddlers could not get enough of the JoyRead program, and it was fantastic fun! 

Feedback from JoyRead participants:

"Oh, Jennifer, we are sad to lose you!...we loved your class and look forward to seeing JoyReads pop up all over the country. We'll be happy to know we were part of it in the beginning."
- Dominique, Royce's Mom

"...the program helped in more ways than one...attention span, routine, and also consistency...this program helped Bridan in so many ways...he was always excited about JoyRead."
 - Frances, Bridan's Mom

"...by the end of the session [my daughter] was in LOVE with letters and reading...I really enjoyed my time during your program."
- Monique, Aubrey's Mom

"We really enjoyed your class...Georgia has learned so much and we sing, 'A You're Adorable' at least twice a day :)"
- Whitney, Georgia's Mom

...and JoyRead Mom, Ivy, wrote me this note: 

My dream is to have JoyRead studios in every state across the USA!...but first we have to start with one. The first-ever JoyRead studio will be located where I live in Southern Maine, near the beautiful city of Portland. Here is a photo of me in front of the space I intend to lease:

With $20,000 as the goal, all profits from your purchase of one or more of the "Perks" listed here will go into JoyRead start-up costs, getting the word out, building out and opening the first JoyRead studio in America. With your support, families with young children will be able to begin a literacy revolution in January 2017!

My goal is to open the first class registration after Thanksgiving, and to offer classes from then onwards. With your help, parents will enter a welcoming, accessible, toddler-friendly space where they will stay to play, and where they will participate in exciting, lively letter and whimsical wordplay classes.

I have just put down a deposit to lease an amazing studio space in Yarmouth, Maine (see above photo)! Already I have invested in legal protections for JoyRead, an application for an LLC, and I've spent thousands of dollars on supplies and toys to use during class.

I am now faced with a major challenge: I need investors who believe in the JoyRead vision so I can make JoyRead a reality first in Maine and then across the USA.

With your support, I will be able to cover launching costs, including: creating and buying printed materials, securing music licensing for the programs, buying ads to market the program, paying for initial rent and utilities, making bright signage for the location, purchasing and creating JoyRead take-homes for registered participants, and purchasing and installing appropriate toddler-safe furniture, fixtures, equipment and supplies to make a marvelous JoyRead Studio.

...you can also help out by clicking "like" on the JoyRead facebook page here.

...for more information about JoyRead, visit the website here.

story:
Influencing Youth Scholarship & Charity Fund is a registered and recognized 501 (C) (3) Charitable Organization. No donation is too small. Please support us and thank you so much with helping us help "Today's Youth become Tomorrow's Future".

Hello, My name is Robert Kelly. I am the President and a Director at Influencing Youth.  

I am retired,  and now spend my time helping and Influencing Youth in several different ways. I find that too often our kids just give up because they can not afford school to better their education. Through a Non-Profit Organization that I have started, I plan to bring on mentors, and teach today's youth technology and designing app's, and help them get a continued education through scholarships.  

We also have chosen partner organizations and are supporting as well as raising money for. These organizations have the best interest of our kids today, organizations such as Youth Outreach Services (YOS), Down Syndrome Association and the Crib/Night Ministry, just to name a few.

We truly believe "Today's Youth is Tomorrow's Future" and today these kids/youth need all the support and help they can get.

Your contribution will go towards helping today's youth with a education and that is something you can be proud of like we are. Eighty-five (85) to ninety (90) cents of every dollar is used to support kids/youths or great partner organizations.

We are looking to raise up to $100,000.00 over the next 6 months. The money raised will go directly to scholarships and donations to assist charities in need. NO ONE at IYSCF receives any pay or salary. We do this because the end result is also our reward, the kids.

Three years ago while awarding a scholarship a mother came up to me after the presentation crying. She wanted to express her gratitude because as a single mother she could not afford the college tuition for her daughter. Because of the scholarship she received her daughter was able to attend college and has continued school with help from more scholarships. Her daughter's sole goal was "to make the world a better place". Needless to say she left me in tears. 

Our project here impacts not only today's youth, OUR KIDS but, OUR future. Why not join us in helping every kid/youth we can so we can make a difference soon.

Most of us never have to deal with wondering where our next meal is coming from or where we will sleep at night. The Chicago Public Schools have over 15,000 kids that attend daily that are homeless. Too many attend school yet don't know where they will sleep. We cannot solve everything or help every child/youth but, we can have an impact on as many as possible with your help.

If you cannot donate/contribute at this time please consider volunteering or donating some time on committees within our organization. and if nothing else please tell all your friends about our campaign here on Indiegogo and use the share tools please. 

Thank you for helping us make a difference in today's youth.

story:
Climate Change 911 is a non-profit organization focused on climate change education. We link inter-sectional issues like justice, women, and animals to climate change through media and activism.

We are a group of climatologists, scientists, educators and activists whose work is guided by one simple truth: We can avoid the worse impacts of abrupt climate change, but we must start to address it now. Our goal by 2020 is to educate, inspire and activate one million children and adults to take a carbon reduction pledge, press for political action, and work on creating healthy, sustainable communities.

We are crowdfunding a climate change outreach campaign and your contribution will help us to publish an informative booklet, the Climate Change Literacy Guide, to train volunteers using the guide and other resources, and to conduct film screenings. 


What We Need & What You Get



Funds raised during this campaign will be used to create and publish the booklet, purchase film screening equipment, recruit volunteers, and conduct outreach campaigns.

Specifically, the money will be used for:

  • creating and publishing a Climate Change Literacy Guide  on climate literacy, climate justice, women & climate, and effects of livestock production ($1000)
  • screen projector and other equipment to show documentaries ($1000) 
  • documentary films like "This Changes Everything," "Merchants of Doubt," "Inside the Garbage of the World," and "Cowspiracy"  ($200)
  • marketing and promotional materials for the campaign ($200)
  • recruiting Volunteer Guides to do screenings and outreach  ($200)
  • training Volunteer Guides on issues and outreach campaigns ($200)
  • contacting schools, libraries and community groups to offer the climate change literacy guide, training and film screenings ($200)
Campaign Supporters will receive credit on our website, digital and printed copies of the Climate Change Literacy Guide, informational posters, and other perks.


The Impact

If you feel that climate change is important and you want to help spread awareness of its dangers and effects, then this climate literacy and outreach project will help to do just that. Acting together, we can affect change! 

Since it was founded two years ago, Climate Change 911 has organized and participated in many events including: art exhibits; the People Climate March in September, 2014; Flood Wall Street demonstrations; other climate protests; and workshops at the Peoples Climate Train, Free University, Soil Not Oil and 21st Century Ecosocialism conferences. Funding for this campaign will help us to reach wider audiences, and be more effective at outreach with Volunteer Guides and informational literature. Plus, if we raise more than $3,000, we may be able to attend the COP21 climate talks in Paris.


Risks & Challenges

People are over-saturated with climate change news and are tuning out. As a result, we may not be able to achieve our goal. However, we will still prepare the climate literacy booklet and use whatever funds are raised to print as much as we can (on recycled paper).

  • We will continue to do outreach and fundraising to obtain screening equipment
  • We will recruit and train a few Volunteer Guides

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
¡Les invitamos a donar en este proyecto de fotografía en las comunidades indígenas migrantes de Los Altos de Chiapas!

¡Con tu apoyo más de 50 niñas y niños podrán acceder a una cámara fotográfica! 

Short Summary: About Voces Mesoamericanas

We are a Mexican civil association that promotes the organization and network-building of indigenous migrants to defend, and exercise their rights, and participate in the construction of “buen vivir,” an indigenous concept of communal well-being, in the transnational communities of Mesoamerica and North America. We promote a focus to regional politics with both long and short-term visions that take into account the structural, economic, and political causes of migration. 

This project is being conducted by Acción Colectiva de Niñez y Juventud Migrante, the program of Voces Mesoamericanas that focuses on children and youth in migration. We utilize artistic skills and projects to encourage the participation, reflection, and expression of young indigenous migrants. This allows us to facilitate their ability to communicate their own perspectives, stories, and future dreams.  

About: Photography Project in Indigenous Communities

Objective:  is to allow children and youth to present their own perspectives of the effects of migration on their communities. The theme is migration but is very open, and within the communities of Los Altos de Chiapas, there will be a focus on internal migration.

This project is necessary and important because, in many research and development initiatives, the migration narrative is presented either directly or through stories and interviews solicited by the researcher. This project aims to enable direct expression of the migrant perspective through an open and raw medium: film cameras. 

What will money go toward: The Voces team facilitators who are involved in this project have agreed to donate their saturdays in order to make this project happen. In this way the costs of this project are very low, with the impact and significance being profound. With 1000 dollars we plan to facilitate this project in 3 more communities.

Donations will go exclusively toward:
1) Printing and developing costs of film (~50%)
2) Transportation (~40%)
3) Material (~10%)

Each project includes three workshops, in which children learn about the meaning of migration and the general theme of the project as well as learn photography skills and gain a clear understanding of the project. The first two workshops take place on consecutive saturdays. The first focuses on migration and photography skills, and the second has a focus on logistical/ technical skills relevant to the use of film cameras. Both workshops include activities, games, and discussions of how to take meaningful photographs that tell stories and can represent their experiences.

If we don't reach the entire goal funds will still be used to facilitate this project but we may have to wait for more funding to complete  the project in all three goal communities  

¿Cuáles son los objetivos?

Animar a que los niños (as) y jóvenes presenten sus propias perspectivas sobre los efectos de la migración en sus vidas y la comunidad. Sabemos que el tema de la migración es muy amplio, por lo que nos enfocamos mucho en abordar la migración interna, debido a la creciente movilidad hacia distintos lugares del país y del estado (la Riviera Maya, los campos agrícolas del Norte de México y los sitios turísticos de las grandes ciudades). Esta iniciativa también pretende facilitar  la expresión directa de la mirada de los y los migrantes a través de un medio abierto y artístico: las “antiguas” cámaras del rollo.Quienes facilitan en este proyecto están donando sus sábados para hacer posible este proyecto. De esta manera los costos se reducen al mínimo. Ya iniciamos en la remota comunidad de La Libertad, en Chenalhó. Calculamos que con 1, 000 dólares podremos facilitar este proyecto en 3 comunidades más.
Las donaciones se destinarán exclusivamente a:
1) Impresión y costo de los rollos (50%)
2) Transporte de facilitadores (20%)
3)Alimentación de los chico y chicas que participan en los talleres (20%)
4) Material de papelería (10%)


The Impact

In addition to the opportunity for children to participate in  a creative art project, and to learn photography skills; this project also carries a much larger impact. The goal of this project includes the objective to strengthen the relationship with these communities, and to support and encourage the involvement of children and youth in other Voces programming or in pursuing their dreams and desires educationally, professionally, and personally. This may include learning how to use computers, further pursuing photography, as well as developing a strong, central, and autonomous political organization in their community. 
Upon completion of the photography project, we will conduct a public presentation of the Museo Migrante (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8YBJCLkOtvM), which serves as a platform for them to share their work, discuss, and take the lead in expressing themselves and their experiences through their photography and other artistic mediums. 

¿Cuál es el impacto?

Además de la oportunidad para que los niños participen en un proyecto de arte creativo, y para aprender habilidades de fotografía; este proyecto también conlleva un impacto mucho más grande. Este proyecto incluye fortalecer la relación con estas comunidades, para apoyar y fomentar la participación de niñas (os) y jóvenes en la búsqueda de sus sueños y deseos desde su propio punto de vista. Esto incluye aprender a usar las computadoras (además del dominio de la fotografía); así como el desarrollo de una organización política fuerte, central y autónoma en y desde la comunidad.  Al término del proyecto, juntos y juntas vamos a realizar una presentación pública de los trabajos en el Museo Migrante (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8YBJCLkOtvM), que sirve como una plataforma para que las niñas, niños y jóvenes indígenas de Chiapas puedan compartir su trabajo, discutir y tomar la iniciativa para expresar sus experiencias a través de la fotografía y otros medios artísticos como el teatro, el cine y la música.

Risks & Challenges

The risks and challenges of this project are very limited as it has been strategically planned out with much thought, conversation, and detail being considered. The main risk to a project in which we give children and youth film cameras, is that something may happen to the camera, or, due to the sensitive nature of film photography pictures will not turn out due to insufficient light, movement, film exposure, etc. Finally, the risk that children or youth with cameras will not return the cameras. 
We have minimized these risks thorough clear instructions about film camera use and an emphasis on the importance of following the tips and instructions they've learned. These risks are also minimized by delegating some of the older youth to oversee the children's use of cameras and to be available to help and support hem. We have also included incentives to returning with the cameras and being careful with the use. For example, in the third and final workshop with the children we will have a celebration and party following the discussion and workshop and will sleep in the community. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not in a position to donate to the campaign, spreading the word through your own personal networks is a huge support- share the campaign with family and friends. This project is incredibly impactful for very minimal costs.
Thanks so much! 

Otras maneras que usted puede ayudar

Si no está en una posición para donar a la campaña, la difusión de la palabra a través de sus propias redes personales es un gran apoyo. Por eso, le invitamos a compartir con  sus familiares y amigos.
Muchas Gracias!
story_txt:
¡Les invitamos a donar en este proyecto de fotografía en las comunidades indígenas migrantes de Los Altos de Chiapas!

¡Con tu apoyo más de 50 niñas y niños podrán acceder a una cámara fotográfica!

story:
Hi, my name is Dana Bender.  I am 21 years old and I am from Albany, NY.  I attend City Harvest Family Church located at 585 Central Avenue in Albany. My profession is a hairstylist, but my passion is to serve people.

I first heard of YWAM (Youth with a Mission) in the winter of 2012 from my pastor.  At YWAM they train young people to be disciples of Jesus and then send them out to spread the Gospel to all the nations.  I was at a crossroad in my life and was tired of living life on my own terms. I knew God had the master plan for my life. When I heard about YWAM, I knew I was supposed to do a DTS (Discipleship Training School). This experience helped me to understand who God is and who I am. I completed my discipleship training school in the spring of 2013 in Maui, Hawaii.  This year YWAM Maui is beginning their very first school of worship; “The Well” which is an in depth journey of seeking the heart of God. I desire to go deeper into the heart of God and to see His glory manifested in my life. I have been feeling drawn to return to Maui for this secondary school. 

The school begins on January 2nd 2016. Financially the entire trip will cost between $9,000 and $10,000. The round trip flight to Maui is around $1,200. The lecture portion of the school is $3850, which includes meals, school materials, transportation, and housing. Finally the outreach portion is estimated to cost between $3,800 and $4,200. I will be investing my own savings, but I need your help! I have some fun and exciting things to give to you when you donate as well.  It may seem like a lot of money and not a lot of time, but I know that all things are possible with God.

 YWAM has been reaching people all over the world with the Gospel of Jesus since 1960. It is one of the world’s largest mission’s organizations today. As a contributor you will be helping to change the world by supporting the Great Commission. Through the school of worship we will be able to reach people for Christ as praise and worship breaks through spiritual walls. Worship also moves the heart of God and connects us with what God is doing.  By supporting me in this trip, I believe you will be helping to release the power of God in my life and the lives of the people in my area of influence.

I have always dreamed of being a worship leader. I want to be able to use the gifts and talents God has given me to worship Him.  I know that worship is so much more than just the songs we sing. My heart is to see people set free and come to a place of truly knowing Jesus. The Well School of Worship will help me to learn different topics of worship such as: Intimacy & Passion for Jesus, Ministering to The Lord, Biblical Basis for Worship, Worship With The Word & Intercession, Personal Freedom, Identity & Character of The Worshiper, Songwriting & Creativity, Foundation of Music Theory, Music Skills Development & Worship Team Dynamics, Worship & Prayer in Revival & Reformation, The Musicianary – Worship in missions today; and much more.

Will you join with me? You can help in several ways. You can contribute financially and through prayer. You can also help to connect me with someone who might have the desire to support missionaries. Another way to help is by sharing this campaign with your friends, family and co-workers. Share this on Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, Google+ and any other social media site you have. This goal can be easily reached. I have a large amount to raise, and a little bit of time; so gifts of $100.00, $500.00 and even $1,000.00 will be needed to see this vision come to pass. So please help by spreading the word!

Your gift will help many experience the closeness we were designed to have with our Creator. Your gift will also help me to fulfill the calling God has on my life.  

If you have any questions, feel free to contact me at bender.dana@ymail.com. You can also learn more about YWAM Maui by visiting their website at www.ywammaui.org.  You can follow my journey by visiting my blog at https://danamitesite.wordpress.com

Mahalo!

story:
Short Summary

The iSmart App will revolutionise the way students with dyslexia and other difficulties learn, study and grow. Initial tests with schools in Sweden, Turkey and the Czech Republic have been so positive that we want to build a better version to reach more countries and more children.

Features

Here are some of the great features that the app will include. With iSmart we are combining several features in one single app.

  Text-to-Speech

  Speech-to-Text

 Mind Mapping

 Highlighting specific characters / letters

  Resource / content sharing

  Fully adaptable text according to learners preference

  Homeworks / Diary

 Parent / Psychologist Portal

  Learning Support Assistant (LSA) support

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking for further funds in order to:

  • Help us release this quicker
  • Make iSmart available in several languages 
  • Ensure iSmart is accessible on all devices (Android , Apple  and Windows )
  • Integrate this in classrooms and schools.

When you crowdfund our cause, we will be doubling the subscription account for you, and also send you a small gift  as a token of appreciation!

If on the other hand you are a serious investor, we will share your love  on our website and even invite you over to Malta to meet us!

The Impact

With 1 in 5 students having some form of learning difficulty, the demand for more assistive technology both in the classroom and at home is very real. We estimate that there are 700 million people in the world with dyslexia at this very moment. Imagine if we could help them all!

We want to ensure that:

  • Students with dyslexia do not feel overwhelmed in class and frustrated at home
  • Parents of children with learning difficulties can now help their kids in a hands on manner
  • Teachers and psychologists can use a technology tool on a 'one-to-one' and 'one-to-many' basis to tailor-make their teaching to the needs of the particular child

Risks & Challenges

It's not going to be easy and we know that this issue could be very easily ignored by many since "special education" is not as exciting as many other business areas. However we believe that this cause will touch the hearts of many parents and many adults who even if they do not have a child with a learning difficulty, but they will believe that something needs to be done and sooner rather than later!

Our challenge is going to be entering several markets at the same time, and finding both investors and business partners to help us understand the needs of the local educational scene, but we are confident that there is enough awareness of this great social need. It might take longer, but we will get there! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot donate now, we would like to ask you to help in one of the following ways

  • Share  our campaign on your social media by using the Indiegogo share tools.
  • Contact us if you are able to connect us with schools in your region.
  • Send us an email with your story if you are in contact with someone with dyslexia or other learning difficulties and help us learn more.
  • Visit our website getismart.com and pre-register your interest there.

story:
I am a professor of ancient history and teach at an university. My satisfying job gives me the opportunity to be immersed in the incredible events of the ancient periods of humanity. I am surprised at how many amazing discoveries modern researchers, including us, discover every day.
Of course, writing reports and describing all these discoveries in scientific circles, we use a boring scientific style, which many readers do not reach to the middle of the reading. The ancient events are stunning and very rich in material life is desire to be known.

Do you realize what kind of adventure you can discover in the world by looking into the depth of the ages?!

Let us open ourselves to the history of our ancestors in a fascinating style of fantasy. We will go along with the heroes of the ancient world on the roads and together we will be saved from the raging rivers and seek refuge in the land hidden under dark clouds. Venturing all the way with them we will discover plenty of excitement in our history, and incredible stories about the loss of millions of peoples from the Tribes of Israel.

We are "reviving" several of the ancient heroic Tribes of the distant past for you. You know one of them was able to get to America and incredible success followed, while another struck it lucky to the diamond industry in South Africa via Holland, and therefore we invite you this incredible journey into the past.
I hope you are ready to join us in this adventure.

This book series will give you as well, the absolute knowledge of the people who once lived in Israel, but were forced to leave the Land, and this series will perhaps be a reflection of the fate of many of today's refugees; those whose roots come from the beloved ancient exiles.

.

AND!!! As you are well aware this is historical, however, the modern world’s financial elite composes mainly of representatives of the Jewish nation.  You will not understand this side of the present world without familiarity of certain aspects of the history of this nation and its historical path.

In the view of the millions of people who are carriers of different cultures: the active role of the Jewish people in the world events were experienced in all periods of human history. Surely the history of the Jewish people and their land is one of the world's oldest seats of civilization – according to Biblical prophecy the land is promised the Jews – and they are an integral part of world culture.

Therefore, each new discovery of "white spots" in this historical arena can be safely regarded as a major breakthrough in the understanding of the formation of civilizations. And, of course, more valuable is the discovery of the "unknown pages" of the historical expulsion of the Israelites and their aspiration to find "temporary shelter" away from the motherland.

I have, as a historian of the ancient Israelite events, already created an in-depth historical academic research project: The research cycle books, "A Historical Research of the Ten Tribes Scattered into the Nations" have been thoroughly developed by our research team for more than ten years.

We spent two years involved with "in-the-field working expeditions" in many countries, personally met representatives of leading local Jewish organizations, and beloved scattered Ten Tribe people of Israel now living outside its borders in new places they call their home. During our expeditions we were blessed to meet local archaeologists, found archaeological evidence of settlements of the ancient Israelite descendants and the connection to the defined recorded events.

All of the academic scientific evidence of "The Research Chronicle" reports on the investigation is available online concerning the glorious and rich sacred history of the Israelites and their intellectual traditions.

Because it will be hard for the ordinary reader
to read the academic material, which is developed
for universities and historical institutions, 
We decided to write this book to fans of
science fiction who want to learn the
historical events of the world more deeply,
but in an easier and captivating format called:

 

In 721 BC after a three-year siege, the Assyrian king Sargon took Israel. He decided to destroy the rebellious Northern Kingdom of Israel. Tens of thousands of Ten Tribe Israelites were taken as prisoners and settled in remote areas of the Assyrian Empire. During the second attempt in 720 BC thousands more were taken from the capital Samaria and other towns and the Northern Kingdom of Israel were emptied. In 586 BC the Babylonian king Nebuchadnezzar captured Jerusalem and deported the Southern Kingdom of Israel, Judah, to Babylon.

Millions of people were expelled from their country by their oppressors. The total number of people who left their homeland can be estimated more than 2.5 million.

How was it possible!!!! 

  •  Especially in the ancient world for masses of people with their livestock to be sustained in the semi-desert middle-eastern counties?
  • Did masses of people leave to other countries before the Assyrian invasions took place?
  • Did the exiled ancient people leave their areas of captivity and venture further into the unknown areas of the New World?
  • Which migration paths did these ancient travellers choose?
  • Where did the megalithic stone structures and dolmens originate from, why do they align with certain heavenly bodies, and are they definite undeniable archaeological signs that the Ten Tribes existed?
  • What is behind the story of the "river that stopped every seven days" to enabling passing over and where is the mysterious land covered by dark clouds?

- Let's imagine  and put ourselves with some of these people on the road; the difficulties in the fight for their faith and their right to live!

To resolve the recorded picture of BC events with progressive views of modern science is not that difficult. This narrative opens an interesting opportunity to shift mind-set and thinking to a fundamentally new relationship between religion and science. Instead of competition there is now cooperation, which is explained by these similarities.

Archaeology has given extensive realistic material, which can be interpreted as traces of the progressive process of life. Similarly, the recorded ancient literature has accumulated a huge stockpile of information about the structure of the physical world and of life in general on the earth, which interpreted as signs of the Creator's act of creation and its progress.

In this series we also find a variety of ancient sources which are very important for the understanding of the life processes of the ancient myths and legends. 

Myth: this is the language in which old men verbally portrayed the most important aspects about themselves. The ancient Israelites thought in pictures, they contributed to the myth-making. That which is expressed in the symbolism of myth opened the human’s understanding and spirit. It very frequently happened that a 'historical fact' evolved into a 'legend', which then turned into a 'myth'. For example it is a historical fact that David slain the giant Goliath. This fact became a legend and today it is told in a story format as a myth, but undoubtedly the facts still remain.

There are many such fascinating myths which were left behind by the people of the Ten Tribes on their migratory routes.

In our world today, all of these historical events have left rich archaeological evidence, which cannot be reasoned away. What is penned in the Scriptures eons ago eventually surfaced for our generation at the end of the 21th century.

A fresh look into history now helps us to find the reason and purpose of our existence in the nations.

The series undoubtedly opens to you the amazing coincidence of mysterious prophecies that come true, proving an undeniable and infallible track-record. It is simply astounding how the Hebrew prophets with their incredible accuracy to predict not only the fate of their people, but also the formation and fall of empires, which had a direct impact on the Jewish people and the ultimate fate of all mankind.

The Ten Tribes’ ancient journeys helped shaping the world...

As stated above, the modern world’s financial elite driving the banking machine, compose mainly of representatives of the Jewish nation, which was shaped by the Israelites that migrated into the various countries years gone by and established the banking systems. You will not understand this side of the world without familiarity with certain aspects of the history of this nation and its historical path.

Discovering these "new white spots" of the history of mankind and the Jews, each of you may realize that basically the world was laid on the supreme law of love and nobility for the human life. This love and nobility to mankind was not granted in vain by the Creator, no, His people now scattered and assimilated into the nations went through tormenting suffering of devastating proportions of all sorts, in the hope to return someday to their real home – the Promised Land.

You reading this, can become part of the greatest prophetic event in history!!!

story:
Introduction

Hi, I'm Ewan and I am the Secretary at the Australian National Aviation Museum. Our museum is all volunteer based and we are a registered Not For Profit group.

Founded in 1965 we now possess one of the most important and complete collections of aircraft and engines in Australia, all from military and civil uses.

This project which is stage two of the Mustang Project is hugely important to us. We rely almost entirely on gate takings and contributions, so our funds are always limited. This year however we pulled off the near impossible and raised $250,000 to acquire the third oldest Australian built Mustang (known as the P-51 in the USA) in the world, and the oldest still residing in Australia.

Built in 1946 the aircraft served with a number of Squadrons before being struck off charge and used as a training aid in Western Australia. It was rescued from this position by an individual who has spent the last 20 years restoring it to hopefully fly, however ill health saw him reluctantly put it up for sale.

Acquiring the aircraft is a massive step as it now completes our collection of Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation made aircraft, a unique achievement.

The aircraft still requires plenty of work and is in a disassembled state. So part of our mission at the Museum is to help train up youth, unemployed and disadvantaged people in some skillsets that may help them find work elsewhere in aviation or other industries that require metalwork, fabrication or restoration.

No whizz bang fancy gadgets on offer here, this is what many restorers call good old fashioned tinbashing!  And we don't use computers or CAD or any of that either. This is done the original way, and in fact using many of exactly the same machines that built these aircraft during the war years. Get it right with a pencil and paper and you won't need to rely on computers to get it right. And with decades of experience with our restorers and metalworkers, those who come on board will get some amazing and special skills indeed.


The Nitty Gritty

So if you choose to come on board what exactly are you helping with ?

1) Trainers and Supervisors - they don't come for free, so we need to help coer their time and effort. All are qualified and or have many years experience working with military and civil aviation companies supplying parts.

2) Materials - Aviation aluminium is not cheap either, and we go through a fair bit of it during restorations, where parts have to be replaced. Also just loads of cleaning tools and more - so much of a restoration involves cleaning down and repainting etc

3) Giving those who are in on the program the skills - we have had some amazing success stories in the last few years. One young man could barely tell one end of a screwdriver from another. Now he is currently on a scholarship with Airbus in Germany. Another was a fresh faced youngster out of school, and a bit lost. Over a few months he learned valuable skills with engines and more, enlisted in the RAAF and is now changing engines on the FA/18 Hornet jets. It can be done, and it doesn't have to be aviation. We know of others who have gone on to general metal fabrications such as stairwells and more. Sounds boring, but for these kids its been a huge bridging step to their future




The Legacy

By coming on board to this project, you are helping us train a new generation to do specialist work in many areas as mentioned - fabrication, restoration, maintenance, conservation, metalwork etc. We do what we do here because we genuinely love it, and nothing makes us more pleased than to have someone come up and say "thank you, I'm learning so much with your help"
Those who are taking part and being trained are also preserving a piece of Australian aviation history - that is important in itself. In the years to come when it is on display, they may come back with their families and friends and say "See that Mustang? I worked on that and helped rebuild it"  It's a pride thing and we will list those that worked on the project on a special board.

Risks & Challenges

The risk we face is we don't raise enough funding to cover the training. It's a real and genuine risk as it may not appeal with it's lack of amazing features so may not be as attractive. If so, the project will still continue but will take a lot longer to complete, years in fact. But consider this for just one moment - you are helping a lot of people get a jumpstart on a career path and that's why we are asking you to help

Other Ways You Can Help

Naturally some of us are a lot less cashed up than others. But hey, you could just let your fingers do the working instead and share this campaign to your friends and families, across all social media and more - it's just a few clicks and you'll feel great for having helped in your own way :) There's a bunch of cool Indiegogo tools you can use to help share as well.

Off we go then !

It's a real and genuine risk as it may not appeal with it's lack of amazing features so may not be as attractive. If so, the project will still continue but will take a lot longer to complete, years in fact. But consider this for just one moment - you are helping a lot of people get a jumpstart on a career path and that's why we are asking you to help 
  Other Ways You Can Help Naturally some of us are a lot less cashed up than others. But hey, you could just let your fingers do the working instead and share this campaign to your friends and families, across all social media and more - it's just a few clicks and you'll feel great for having helped in your own way :) There's a bunch of cool Indiegogo tools you can use to help share as well. Off we go then !
